review_title: You're just a number to the company
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: -For a first job out of college, you'll get some good learning experience and will work in a traditional tech setting -Decent benefits with a good lounge and gym on site -Coworkers are amazing. Very intelligent, kind, and interesting people to work with. It's easy to make friendships here
cons: The company does not care about its employees. The corona virus crisis highlighted this more than ever. When every other tech company in the area and the country was encouraging their employees to telework, MicroStrategy kept insisting everyone should be in the office unless they have an "extreme emergency". None of their emails ever stressed that the company was concerned about their workforce, they only mentioned how important the customers are. Furthermore, the CEO's personal email to the company was one of the most unempathetic things I've ever read. He spoke about the crisis in terms of statistics, saying that we shouldn't worry because there are much worse diseases out there. The icing on the cake: he essentially wrote "some people will die but they're old so its okay, we really need to worry about the economy". If you end up here get what experience you can in the first two years then go elsewhere that actually thinks of its workforce like people and not numbers to their bottom line

review_title: The rats on the Titanic had a more hopeful outlook
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: Your co-workers are mostly awesome and friendly. This is a lot of employees first job out of college, so definitely a more "youthful" feel in the department. You'll bond and become friends in the communal suffering. You can tell the immediate management cares to some degree, but they have absolutely no power to change anything. The offices & free food were nice.
cons: Oooooh boy here we go. You'll be trained to support a product that is quickly becoming antiquated in the BI industry. You know what I love regarding installing an enterprise level business intelligence platform in the year 2020? Manually editing multiple text configuration and XML files. Or the UI on our Developer tool still stuck in the 90s. It's becoming increasingly complex to manage as a platform, and most companies are moving to newer and sleeker options. I hope you have a good hat rack with many hooks, because you'll acquire quite a collection. Previously, the department was separated by product specialty. Makes since, right? It's such a complex product, and takes a new engineer anywhere from 1-1.5 years to really become familiar with supporting it. Now, you'll be expected to support every aspect of the product. Jack of all trades, master of none. On top of that, they got rid of the Technical Account Managers, so you'll have the awesome option of taking on those responsibilities for no extra pay. Oh, expect to be asked to work late supporting some big important escalation. Yes, we have teams in Europe and Asia who could support their hours better. But that's okay. Also, we have 24x7 support on weekends, so expect a weekend or two a quarter of being on call the entire time. Yes, even at 4am. Also, I hope you enjoy being forced to not only be on call with all of our customers, but also share your webcam with them! Don't mind that people in IT support tend to be introverts or not want to be in the spotlight. Or the eventual sexual harassment incidents that will occur to any of the few remaining female employees. We used to have neat team events, those got axed long ago. Free food once a week usually was nice pre-COVID. Your compensation will be "meh" at best for a new college grad, and will only get worse. The engineers who choose to stay at MicroStrategy stay because of the people and the work culture. The people are mostly gone, and the culture has been burnt to the ground by executive management who swear they know best. The small quarterly bonus you do get (which is subject to company performance, so not too optimistic on that) is pitiful and doesn't scale with your salary, if you're lucky enough to see a raise. Also, they used to give yearly COL raises of like 2%, but that went out the door. Mike must need a new yacht (no, seriously).

review_title: If you're willing to put in the work you will learn a lot and make a lot
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: Not really pros, but a list of what you need to know when you take this job: 1. You have to be self-motivated and willing to teach yourself. You can form an internal network to assist with any issues, but for the most part it will be referencing documentation and tech notes to be up to date with customer issues. 2. You have to enjoy challenges. You will face a lot and have to be willing to problem solve like your life depends on it. 3. You get out what you put into it. If you put in minimal effort, customers won't have nice things to say and you won't be recommended to work with them again. If you put in the effort to learn and meet customer expectations, you'll do fine. 4. DEFINITELY expect travel especially at the beginning. Once you're established, it's easier to find remote work (if that's what you want) and customers that are okay with it. You'll still have to travel every once in a while, but not nearly as often. This also really depends on the customer. I went from traveling about 50% of the time to about 10% or where the customer gave me the choice to travel or work remote. I absolutely love my job, but I'm also someone who loves challenges and doesn't like to be bored.
cons: It's consulting, which means everything comes down to how much revenue you bring in. You don't usually get to choose the projects you're on, which means you don't really get to choose how much money you bring in, which means your rating doesn't always seem fair. With that being said: being proactive and helping internally when there is not a lot of billable work is important and can make up for less time working with customers.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 8 years
pros: MicroStrategy is a well known brand with multiple offices located around the world, providing an international flavor depending on your role. There are some very good, bright people at the company, however, the best and brightest are generally the quickest to look for the exits. The company will test your ability to endure pain and suffering in your career, providing a great opportunity to learn a lot about yourself in the process. The company offers above average benefits and has a 401k match program, however, there are no RSU's or ESPP. Compensation in the US and in select international locations is generally fair.
cons: This is an incredibly dysfunctional company that is run by an autocratic leader, surrounded by a C-Suite that has been hired to re-affirm him, not to challenge him. As a result, the company is replete with cliques, heavy-handed top-down management decisions, and political gamesmanship that operates within a fear-based culture of conformity. Employee reviews are subjective and ratings given to direct reports are typically lowered by upper management overruling middle management decisions. Middle managers have no real power to make decisions for their teams with all decisions resting upon the final approval of MJS, who is often manipulated by his direct C-Level reports. The company has been losing market share and stays in business because of customer renewals and the CEO's billions. Very few net-new licenses are ever sold and they are not competing well against other leading players in the BI space. The poor showings in the Gartner Magic Quadrants is justified internally by saying Gartner has changed their methodology rather than acknowledging product shortcomings and closing those gaps. MicroStrategy does not offer stock options (RSU's or ESPP) and doesn't offer anything to build long term employee loyalty. The fastest way to a raise or a promotion is to either threaten to leave or to actually leave and then return to MicroStrategy -- there are many boomerangs who have negotiated better opportunities for themselves by going this route.

review_title: Use caution or avoid all together
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for less than a year
pros: Handful of great people free parking decent coffee nice gym
cons: Overall Business Perspective: - Very little to be optimistic about here. I foresee the company experiencing more challenges as current customers leave to implement more flexible well-rounded solutions that are native to the cloud, and, are likely cheaper as well. - From a Gartner Magic Quadrant perspective, hard to see MicroStrategy maintaining challenger status. As more customers leave, I would predict niche player status sooner rather than later. Not being a native cloud based solution will continue to hold them back and because IT involvement is so necessary in implementation, it's tough to envision anything but a decline from Gartner in the future. - Financials are weak. Publicly traded so all information is available and would highly recommend reviewing.... Income statement should strike concern in any sound investor. Revenue and gross income down year over year at a steady pace since 2015 (maybe even longer). Net cashflow trends are even worse… Leadership: -Revolving door lol Personal Experience: - Reported to a VP who was difficult to work with. - Much of management was difficult to work with, I suspect because they struggled to understand the priorities of the day, week, month, etc. because of the lack of strong institutional guidance. - I'd describe the environment as "just trying to keep the ship from sinking" at all times. How it ended: - Left a really good job for an opportunity at MicroStrategy to help with quite a few process changes and upgrades. Once everything was seemingly completed and a lot of the painpoints were resolved, was laid off without any warning. My only guess to why... light revenues were being seen yet again, and leadership had to cut costs to try to save on revenue margins???? Or they just wanted an extra set of hands to help with some short term issues they were dealing with, and once everything was good then there was no need for me any longer. Either way, tough way to treat employees Long Story Short: - Use caution or avoid completely. - Not worth the risk and better off where you are now or continue searching for a stronger company

review_title: Good place to start but not to stay
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The pros are in the people and the location. There are some very intelligent and kind people at the company. Everyone always seems to have a good attitude and are willing to help each other out. For a first job out of college, it is great. The starting pay is alright (albeit a little under the market rate), you develop some strong skills, and the culture is fun. The work life balance is fairly good too. Aside from some tension close to releases, work generally stays in the office and people's lives aren't heavily impacted outside of work hours. Beyond that the office is great. A gym on location, a lounge with plenty of free coffee and other drinks, and the office is located right next to the best mall in the entire DMV area. There's a good holiday party too.
cons: The cons amount to so much more than the pros. While lower and middle management are amazing the upper management is a constant headache. There is a blatant divide between the upper management and the rest of company. Far too often, upper management blatantly ignores what workers are asking for. When 80% of employee responses in a public survey asked for more remote work opportunities, the management ignored this and instead addressed a request for ice cream that was clearly a joke response. It felt like such a slap in the face to not even have our complaints acknowledged and to be given ice cream as if we're children. Upper management's decisions are all over the place. The "company direction" is always getting rerouted and projects that have been significantly developed are suddenly scrapped when the upper management decides to develop something else. There's an environment of fear where a lot of decisions made at a lower level are just to please the CTO and, especially, the CEO even when they don't make sense from the perspective of engineering and product quality. Furthermore, upper management is constantly too ambitious and expects far too much to be developed for the amount of people the company has. There are regularly last minute changes in scope and patches being rolled out because everything that was demanded was unachievable from the beginning. Product quality ends up suffering and key issues get patched over without being truly fixed. The company does not do nearly enough for retaining quality employees. I can't imagine what went through management's heads when they decided to make a huge hiring push AND gave all the new hires large increases in their starting salaries. Now we're losing experienced engineers because there isn't enough money to go around for the raises and promotions they deserve. Some people who have multiple years of experience under their belt are making barely a few thousand over the fresh college hires. This has created a high turnover among junior employees that seems to be getting worse and worse every year. Engineers with the most potential quickly jump ship for a company that pays them what they should earn. Lastly, I have to mention that recruitment straight up LIES to candidates. They advertise that new engineers will get to choose their teams, will always receive the full quarterly bonus, and will receive automatic promotions. All of this is untrue. The financial incentives change every quarter and even the standard 1 year promotions aren't guaranteed. Everyone is assigned to teams regardless of their preferences as well. I'm not sure if this is a disconnect between recruiting and management but it needs to stop as it quickly sours new employees once they realize they've been lied to and drives the high turnover rate of younger employees that I mentioned earlier. Like I said, this is a good first job out of college but that's it. I would not grow a career here based on how the management is performing.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Having left the company for another software company, I can appreciate that there are decent, somewhat forward thinking engineering processes at MSTR. Appropriate emphasis on quality and testing and super intelligent engineers at MSTR.
cons: Where do I start with the ? The Technology department is ruled by "The Old Boys Club" and you are made very much aware by this group if you are not one of the cool kids. Arrogance and "I said so, so do it" are the way the Technology leadership team manages. Obviously in a software company there are ebbs and flows of stress/work hours right before a release, but at MSTR, tensions always run high about 1-2 months before a release and the way in which people treat each other exudes disrespect and toxicity. This trickles down from management and creates an atmosphere of general lack of kindness. This is a company where only heroes are celebrated. You must prove your mettle by showing up early, staying late, coming in on weekends, and above all else *making sure you are seen and heard doing that.* Several months ago it was mandated that EVERY SINGLE Technology give up their entire weekend (shortly before the holidays) even if there was no pending work to be done by you/your team. The understanding was -- just come in , and make sure you are seen by someone by senior management. Only SuperStars are celebrated here, not Rock Stars -- the ones that fly under the radar but consistently get their job done, day in and day out. I will take a less visionary or pivotal software company where people treat each other kindly any day over a company like MSTR which, while having admittedly excellent Technology, has an internally dysfunctional and toxic work culture.

pros: Nice location, spacious office, interesting product
cons: Where do I begin? Lets start with the most important aspect for anyone in business development – commission. The commission plan is fluid to put it kindly. You can have absolutely no confidence in the commission plan as it changes non stop, this could be due to the constant changes in senior management however the fact that it seems to change whenever there is potentially some large commission to pay out due to deals about to come in has led me to believe its something more planned and sinister. I have come to the firm conclusion that there is somebody in the CFO office who is actively instructing the sales department to adjust the commission plan accordingly in order to minimise commission paid. This would be in line with the general drive to minimise costs in the last 12 months. The company has been boasting about recruitment numbers etc, however this hides the fact that new recruits seem to be coming in on minimal salary while a lot of the higher earners in senior management appear to have been shown the exit. With the constant drive to minimise commission and the clear message of driving down costs it does lead one to wonder if the company is in worse shape than they are stating in there financial reporting (which wouldn’t be the first time!) Next up I will touch on the culture / atmosphere at work. To be completely frank it appears to be little more than a cult worshipping the CEO / Chairman of the Board / President -(all the same person by the way lol). Any senior management who dare disagree with anything the great leader says doesn't last long. Which obviously leads to yes men all through the chain of command. I can honestly say I have not had one manager who I actually respected in terms of how they do their job. Everyone lives in fear of the great leader and this obviously permeates every aspect of working their, to the extent that as part of their reviews they have everyone anonymously rate others performance, which is obviously used to settle scores. Anyone familiar with the tactics of the great cultural revolution? Is that's your thing then MSTR (Microstrategy) is the place for you! . Anyway I have better things to be doing than spending time on this company, I would just urge any BDR looking to join MSTR to avoid this company. You will not get the commission you are promised and the fact that they are actively minimising the commission they are paying may point to something far more serious in terms of their future viability. Finally, it is quite amusing to see all the poorly written, short, positive reviews with no likes. If i didn't know better I would have to question whether they were genuine... Thanks for taking the time to read this

main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good starting salary. Good location. It's a good job if you're starting out. Your co-workers are going to be very smart, friendly, helpful and kind, with no backstabbing competitiveness. I must admit, it's easy to take this for granted from time to time.
cons: The cons are mostly about the management, so I'm going to divide my criticism into 3 parts: direct manager, his manager, and company management/direction. 1. Direct Manager: Extremely inexperienced as a manager. He will always rush you to "fix defects" as soon as possible. Direct managers are not technical at all and will have absolutely no interest in writing good code, dealing with tech debt, understanding the technical challenges of whatever you're working on, etc. They are apparently measured just on the number of defects, so that's what he is focused on at all times. He has an extremely negative presence, and the team feels it. He will make up arbitrary deadlines (often tells the team things like "upper management has asked for this", which no other team can corroborate) and convince you to stay till 7 or 8 pm to work, and, funnily enough, he would leave at 5. Feedback during one-on-ones is non-existent. He would say that he doesn't decide the score out of 5 that we get (he says everyone got a 3, literally every time), or our bonus, or our review, or our raises. When asked how to improve, I have heard the same thing every quarter: do more of what you're doing, which isn't very specific or helpful. It does not seem like he is accountable to anyone for how unprofessionally he handles reviews. He has also forbidden us from spending time during work learning things, which, for software engineers, is incredibly stifling and uninspiring. All in all, possibly the worst manager you can have. Furthermore, there isn't a proper channel to voice my concerns, so there's not much I can do here. 2. His manager: Usually managers in this position are people who have worked at Microstrategy for more than 10 years. So they are very used to how things are done and are very averse to changes in technologies or updates. There is an incredible amount of red tape if you want to voice your ideas, which is why hackathons are such a big deal. It's the only time when employees can work on projects that they think are cool. Some of the best ideas recently have through hackathons. However, senior managers seem to not be interested in those at all in the last couple of years. As such, it's a dull environment intellectually. You will rarely even get to speak to him (might be specific to this particular manager), and he will not know your name or what you're working on. Also, your raises will be less than inflation, which is really disappointing, but not unexpected since he wouldn't even know your name. 3. Upper management ends up deciding everything about the technical direction of the product. Directions change drastically and we are constantly scrambling from one area of focus to another, with no transparency or good communication. Managers get the most visibility and often micromanage about which features or new things we should be working on. We have a number of core values: transparent, agile, precise, cheerful and engaged. Microstrategy technology department fails on all of them.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: Company pays well and has a great benefits package. Overall the company tends to hire smart, qualified staff and does show interest in helping them grow. MicroStrategy is a company you can grow in IF you are beloved by senior management and the executive team.
cons: MicroStrategy continues to perform their annual practice of laying off employees with zero advanced notice and a laughable severance package. The CFO starts the year off bragging about how the company has grown by nearly 800 employees and that the financial outlook of the company is so strong that they took advantage of their high performance to buyback some of the companies stock. Not even a month later layoffs begin happening across the company. Including departments that backfilled positions or were even given permission to grow in order to perform better as the company grew. If you look at the history of many of the employees at MicroStrategy you will notice gaps of tenure, former employees returning to the company after being denied a promotion to only be given it after returning, and favorite employees being placed in positions that they are wholly unqualified for. MicroStrategy is a company who spends more time taking care of its executive floor and making sure that their whims are taken care of over ensuring that the business is healthy, profitable, and that its' "most important asset, you, the employee" are being addressed. The executive team all have their yes-men that they listen to while ignoring anyone else who might be bringing up information that needs to be shared but doesn't want to be heard. Seeing the history of this company in the press, the direction the industry is moving, and the way this company carries itself in how it conducts business; I would strongly recommend that you look elsewhere for future employment and that current employees keep their resumes well polished and nearby because you never know when you will get that ominous meeting invite in your mailbox.

review_title: Poor BD Management - Tough Position - Questionable Company
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for less than a year
pros: - Established technology company - Free gym - Reasonable benefits if you're a full-time employee - Paid holidays and vacation that you're discouraged to use - Above industry base pay, below industry comission - Fun company sponsored events for employees (attendance is often discouraged by BD management) - Newly renovated employee lounge - Discounted FitBit - company encourages fitness - Free beverages and games in the lounge - Next to Tysons Mall - Exclusive company indoor parking garage for all employees - Spacious and comfortable work-cube areas - Intelligent, fun, and professional co-workers - Exposed to the full spectrum of a corporation - complete hierarchy and all departments - Impressive, modern office building Related to BDR position: - A difficult, but possible career path for a very small percentage of BDR's - Intelligent Account Executives that you can learn from - Free snack or breakfast every Friday - Occasional company-paid travel to company events - Free laptop - Company sponsored happy hours, usually once every few weeks after-work - Company sponsored intramural sports
cons: - The gym is small and often crowded - Many departments communicate poorly with each other - Different culture for each department / segregated company culture - Company struggling on many levels. Related to BDR position: - Limited and ineffective training - BD management is woefully undertrained, inexperienced, undersupervised, and inefficient - Stale, outdated, and unrealistic metric goals for NA considering expansion of department - Inconsistent expectations by management - Inconsistent advice given to BDR's by management - Inconsistent enforcement of rules - The company values of "engaged" , "transparent", and "cheerful" are all laughably absent from BD leadership. - tant revolving door. BDR’s are "asked to leave" frequently and continuously, often times for reasons outside of their control. Some BDR's are given enough time to find another job. Others are ruthlessly fired on the spot, with no warning, and with no given reason. - Repetitive and unfulfilling job tasks - Management likes to hire new BDR’s as contractors, so they can be fired with minimal paperwork - As a contractor, you get no benefits. - The real training is done by failing at your job, talking to your outside sales team, and talking to other co-workers who were trained at other companies - Data in the CRM tool is manipulated by BDR's and ignored or promoted by management to boost artificial BD numbers for the department to make BD management look competent. - Meeting writeup process is illogical and non-productive - BDR's are setup for failure in most circumstances, and every day you fight to keep your job. There is no such thing as job security here. You feel like a hamster on a wheel working here. - Toxic BD management: unprofessional behavior and treats employees poorly. Includes name calling, cursing, negative intimidation, anti-social behavior, and unethical practices - Anti-social behavior and unethical practices by management are notoriously well known among BDR’s but no action is taken and no one speaks up due to fear of repercussions - Quarterly reviews of management are not accurately rated due to fear of someone in HR or BD management finding out who wrote it, and fear of repercussions. - Management has decided that fear and intimidation are the best way to rule and dominate over their BDR minions. This is a big misstep for these BD overlords, and truly a very faulty way to run a department and to treat anyone. In return, the BDR team has no respect for management. This doesn't incite positivity which is desperately needed for a position like this where so much rejection and negativity already exists without management amplifying it. Management routinely finds new and innovative ways to crush BD team comradery. I wrote this review primarily to warn those looking at this position. Like most jobs, it's oversold to you, but you may not realize the type of negative and degrading atmosphere you'll be stepping into once you're hired. There are much better companies in the DC area who will train you and treat you right. Commission here is only 1/3rd of what was offered only a few years ago. This company tries everything it can to avoid paying out commission, your base pay is mostly what you'll get. Management here is very shallow. By far these have been the worst bosses I've had the dissatisfaction to work for. I have nothing bad to say about any of my other bosses at other jobs, they were always seen by me as good people trying their best and helping you to do your job well. The bosses I've had here are nothing like the one's I've had in the past. Completely toxic. Avoid.

Obviously, this is designed such that no one can achieve their 100% merit bonus! As someone who is accustomed to being a rockstar at her job, I felt slighted whenever I didn't receive the shiny 5 stars. In my first review, I was demerited as a result of not being exposed to enough of my job responsibilities up to that point in time -- and this was actually acknowledged to be of no fault of mine. In later reviews, my demerits were due to comparison to the team - my peers had already been placed in charge of larger projects prior to my hiring (and were unwilling to share much of the workload), so they received singing accolades, whereas I was left in the dust. My abilities were never factored in. Onboarding literally did not exist: As a new hire, I was given nothing to do for months. I actually decided to work as a contractor for another company in my spare time after my requisite 8 hours in the office, just so that I wouldn't feel depressed about how under-utilized I was. I would have resigned sooner (along with the other new hire in my group) if I hadn't made a promise to myself to give it a full year. New ideas unwelcome: When I was finally given tasks, I was kept on a short leash. I tried but was usually shot down when trying to introduce efficiencies and new ideas. I was kept at a distance and often out out of the loop. Too many cooks in the kitchen that were all very set in their ways. How could I be expected to be a shiny 5-star employee with roadblocks everywhere I turned? Management: Unapproachable. My boss never gained trust in my abilities because she simply chose not to interact with anyone besides her favorite employees (of which I was certainly not), except on a weekly or when absolutely needed basis. I have never worked for or with anyone so unapproachable. Negative atmosphere: While the rest of the team was mostly friendly, the overall atmosphere was unpleasant and constantly stressed. Even the friendly ones were like an old club that would head out to happy hour and exclude me regularly. I like a fast-paced demanding role, but I could do without the negativity that is clearly rewarded at MSTR. Inflexibility: While some team members were allowed to work remotely 100% of the time and others dabbled with it frequently, I was actually denied a request to work remotely for 1 day (not even PTO), which resulted in my missing an event that I'd hoped to attend. The reason given was the desire to have a minimum number of folks from the team in the office on that day - a mid-quarter Friday during which I was, as usual, underutilized. Moreover, nothing about the job responsibilities requires presence in office. As for PTO, 15 days at a manager level is pretty weak. One of my teammates was constantly being hassled for the sometimes flexible hours she chose to work (while the work was getting done, and in her role there was no logical reason that she needed to be working within a rigid window). My philosophy simply did not align; I think flexibility should be rewarded where the work is getting done and the focus should be on the work product rather than "hours clocked".

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for less than a year
pros: * Great enterprise BI softwares * Great location of the HQ building * Decent pay and benefits * Food truck and Thirsty Thursday in summer * Quarterly performance review allows for quick feedback from the management, which is helpful for improving performance and expectation.
cons: I was quite surprised that MicroStrategy still uses the stack/forced ranking approach to review its employees that had been proven a failed system for performance evaluation by Yahoo, Microsoft, etc a few years ago. During the quarterly performance review process, managers use a number between 1 - 5 to rate the employees (1 being the worst and 5 the best), and they curve the performance ratings within each team, meaning that a small fraction of the team members get a 1 or 2, and smaller fraction get 4 or 5, while the majority get a passing score of 3. Almost all of us consider the following to be equivalent: 1 = F, 2 = D, 3 = B, 4 = B+, 5 = A Even if you are a new hire, your performance is reviewed without lenience. To be honest, I got a low rating three months after I joined the company. Never had I got a such low performance rating in my entire career or school life till that point, I was totally frustrated. I tried my best to learn the new gig, and yet the manager considered that to be NOT good enough. I feel like MicroStrategy does not allow the new people to take time for learning, instead the manager expects new hires to hit the road and start running on day one, which is unrealistic expectation for people who come from a different field than BI. As a new hire, your first 3 - 4 weeks are spent 100% on the bootcamp, leaving only 8 - 9 weeks for actually learning/doing the work. My first perf review results made me question whether the company is good fit for me, so I made myself back on the job market. A few months later, I quit and landed on a bigger company that offers a better compensation package and probably a better career path, too.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: Central location (Tyson's, adjacency to mall, etc.), gym, nice modern building, as noted by many other reviewers. Also, employee lounge with pool table, if that sort of thing interests you. Flexible work hours. Working remotely is frowned upon, but building elevator is busiest around 10 pm and 5-6pm. Some minor but industry-average employee discounts at tech retailers like Apple and Dell. Ridiculously talented technology workforce in China and HQ. These are the architects, programmers and testers that pour countless hours into building company's products and reducing technical debt in the face of continuous cultural and organizational challenges, never-ending realignments of product strategy and a caustic work environment.
cons: It is not at all surprising that this company with great potential has been marred by trouble after trouble in many directions. The now-infamous 2014 letter from Apex Capital to the CEO telling him to dock the yacht may have been spot-on but did not bode well for the rest of the company: Saylor came back with a vengeance and started micromanaging every nook and cranny of each product in the company's portfolio. This happens in many companies and the user that product management has to react to and satisfy is not only the customer but also the executive sponsors; but in the case of MSTR, these executives are a socially inept CEO that listens to noone but himself, a CTO that is even more socially inept than the CEO, with no technical acumen or leadership skills to speak of, and a string of yes-men (mostly men) from the CTO all the way down, that have time and again seen that the the key to survival in a company that did reorgs once a month at some point is never disagreeing with the CEO lest face, at best public humiliation over email, and at worst, termination. The company was run with no governance and internal accountability like an early stage start-up for many years and the efforts to rectify that were ham-handed at best. Paying a large sum for Agile Scrum management software, management tried to institute a time-recording system using that platform, raising the ire of many employees in the development ranks. Years and years of never having done real performance reviews and not having kept performance records, the company enabled senior director or VP-level people to directly grade hundreds of employees based on no feedback whatsoever from them or their supervisors; the effort to start performance management took off pretty much as a formality, where rankings and promotional considerations still continued to be based on factors other than real merit. When MSTR ventured into identity HR made colossal mistakes by stacking the senior management of that effort with non-technical product executives from security companies. And when all failed without a proper GtM strategy, they rebranded overnight into a security product, which finally fizzled out into an add-on feature for the BI suite. The bitterness from management mistakes and the executive rank's reactions to developments in a publicly-traded company results in very poor morale in the workforce and subsequently super-high attrition rates quarter after quarter. To HR's credit they tried every trick in the organizational behavior playbook: An employee council that tried to make employees feel empowered through anonymous surveys? Check. Super-high referral bonuses? Check. Happy hours? Check. Food truck free lunches instead of serving leftover food from the executive floor on other floors' kitchens? Check. But, the fact remains that most of the employee base is either looking for jobs elsewhere or scheming to rise. Another indicator of the poor health of the company is the vast divide between perceptions of success in different groups. Business Development or Engineering folks can be right in the middle of this misery (unless they are senior level folks that know how to play their cards right) while Legal or Marketing folks can be blissfully unaware of the fires going on among the development teams.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: My team was full of smart, helpful, kind people, and they are the only thing I truly miss about MicroStrategy. The gym was nice, as was the easy access to the mall. Work/ life balance was good on my team, but that is not true company-wide.
cons: If you are a recent grad/ early-career, stay far away. Many teams use old tech with bad code quality, and some products aren't unit tested at all. If you are lucky enough to be on a team using modern tech, expect to work long hours while upper management breathes down your neck. You will always be pushed to finish tasks as quickly as possible, even at the expense of code quality, documentation, and testing. Management needs to improve. Middle management only served to pass down orders from the top. Ideas from lower-level employees were often ignored and concerns were often dismissed out of hand. Everyone is expected to be a yes-man, and the culture is based in fear. I have seen managers yell and lash out at team members in anger. The review/ promotion/ raise process is incredibly biased and, frankly, illogical. Team members with different responsibilities and experience levels essentially fight for the same promotions, which fosters competition and discourages teamwork. Upper management will push lower-level managers to lower an employee's review score just to limit the number of good reviews in the team. It is also difficult to figure out how you need to improve in order to be considered for a raise, as there are no leveling charts or written job descriptions. Management loves to talk about how "transparent" they are, but that really couldn't be further from the truth. It was not unusual to come in to work to find that your team's responsibilities had completely changed overnight. Some might say that this is a by-product of how "agile" the company is, but I believe it is possible to be agile while still communicating effectively with your employees. The salaries are fairly competitive, but the other benefits could be better. The company is very proud of their Lynda usage, but Lynda is not a substitute for tuition reimbursement or conference attendance. Other perks like Food Truck Fridays and the pool table do not make up for everything else.

review_title: The problems here are NOT normal.
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: - Reasonably flexible PTO - Nice gym in the building - Good people at the team-level - Some strong friendships made through shared suffering
cons: Some other reviews on this site and some former colleges of mine have said essentially, “Sure, there are some problems here, but all workplaces have issue like this”. It is true, all companies have problems…but VERY FEW can possibly have as many as MicroStrategy. The biggest issue for me at MicroStrategy was the work environment. Pure and simple, the majority employees are not happy with their job there. There is a lack of motivation and passion for the work – almost no one has any interest in doing their job from day-to-day aside from appeasing their manager. This problem stems from a variety of causes, but in a large part is the aftermath of a massive round of layoffs in 2014. The company went from ~3500 employees worldwide to right around ~2000 over a year, many of these were laid off while the rest was due to subsequent attrition. A lot of the best people at the company abandoned ship during this period, leaving huge gaps in leadership and leading to numerous restructures. People talk openly about their job hunts and joke about who would be the last person left at the company. When I heard of friends leaving the company for other jobs, my disappointment at their departure was dwarfed by my excitement that they had been able to escape to somewhere better. There have been half-hearted attempts by management to improve the atmosphere, e.g. “Food Truck Fridays”, but the continued attrition and lack of real change has lead me to guess that they have concluded it is really not worth their effort to retain employees at this point. Benefits and compensation are less than competitive, as salary reviews will show. The majority of engineers are internationals on work visas, which is cheaper than paying competitive salaries to US software engineers. It feels like these international engineers are being taken advantage of – luckily many of them have moved on to places like Google and Facebook. The 401k plan is egregious. The company will half-match your 6% contribution (low compared to comparable companies) but read the fine print in the vesting timeline! A meager 20% vests after 2 full years there, and you have to be there for 6 YEARS for 100% vesting. Add to that that the plan is with Principal, a group notorious for high fees that eat away your retirement savings. Everything about the company of late feels like they are penny-pinching, from huge hassles submitting expense reports, to cancelling cell phone plans, to replacing forks and spoons in the kitchen with sporks (is this an elementary school cafeteria!?). Upper management is abysmal, as could be gathered from the CEO approval rating. No one has the courage to stand up to executives when they make terrible decisions, which is not surprising since most that have made a stand did not last long at the company. Many low-level managers are good people, but they are powerless to help their team advance their careers or protect them from nonsensical decisions and mandates from higher-ups. Good, hard workers are rewarded by piling more work on them. Your best chance at getting a raise or promotion is to say you are quitting (which, to be fair, seems to be pretty effective). On top of all this, the MicroStrategy product is profoundly flawed and is being outdone by competitors like Tableau at every turn. Keeping the product from becoming more and more obsolete every year takes the combined efforts of the entire technology department. The largest source of revenue is from support (this should say something about the quality of a product…) and from customers that have been invested for 10+ years that have put so much time and energy into maintaining the convoluted platform that they can’t bring themselves migrate to a better solution. It is truly a struggle to get excited about building and selling something that is just not very good. To anyone considering taking a job here, I’d strongly advise against it no matter the stage in your career. Look at rating trends and understand that many of the 5-star reviews are from current employees who were asked to write good reviews by management. To anyone currently working there, know that these problems are NOT normal and a workplace can be miles better. I’ve moved on and could not be happier to be at a different company. TL;DR – Work environment is miserable, management doesn’t care about employees, product is bad, don’t work here.

review_title: Seasoned, career-driven professionals know to avoid MSTR
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: Just as companies have to weed out good candidates from the bad, you also to need to weed out bad companies that will waste your time and cripple your career. So, if you are reading this review because you are considering working at MSTR, the good news is you are NOT currently working at MSTR. Run, don't walk, away now. Ask any executive, recruiter, or placement professional in the Metro area about this place, and they will laugh and tell you to avoid like the plague. If you ARE currently working at MSTR, my condolences and good luck in your job search. Take some comfort in knowing you are learning exactly how NOT to run a company, treat employees, and earn respect. It will pay dividends in the future. As most reviews mention, the Tysons location and the on-site gym are the only real benefits of working at MSTR. Other than that, you will only find occasional glimmers of hope within the company. For example, you will find some talented staff, but they are slowly wasting away or leaving in droves.
cons: The staff are mostly trying to do their best, but the problem is with the system. There are deep systemic management issues that are beyond repair. When leadership fails, the company fails. Saylor gets a lot of flack as CEO of the company, but he does deserve credit as a visionary and entrepreneur. His biggest mistake, next to Usher, was empowering Tim Lang as CTO, as the biggest issues are found within the Technology division. Decision making is not decentralized, and the CTO continues to show why he is not fit to lead. If you have ever taken any leadership classes, you will be astounded to learn the CTO fits NONE of the criteria that defines an effective leader. With all the charisma of a block of wet tofu, he has no ability to unlock the intrinsic motivation of knowledge workers. No one will follow this man into battle, as they have all learned that his commitment to quality and productivity are a scam, because he has no idea what is actually needed. He has never walked in the trenches or even met many of his own direct reports. He sets new strategy each quarter, never realizing that in an Agile environment, culture eats strategy for lunch. And Agile at MSTR is a complete joke! It was rolled out to staff without any training, company buy-in, or vetting of tools. Even the most basic principles, such as develop on cadence and release on demand are ignored. Leaders that are true developers of people are not valued and are quickly and barbarically terminated, only to be replaced by narrow and self-interested "yes" men. Knowing that your CTO has an enormous impact on your day-to-day quality of life at work, such as what projects you work on, recognition you receive, professional development, and bonus payout, the entire Technology department is hosed. For example, your quarterly bonus will not be based on performance, but rather the CTO's algorithm of the month. Supervisor input is completely ignored. The staffing breakdown at MSTR looks like this: 50% are actively searching for new jobs; 40% are held hostage by their H-1B status; 5% are complacent, and 5% are narcissistic senior managers that can't see past their own ego. That is why the churn is 10-15% per quarter, and you will never work on a stable team. Be sure to read the latest Gartner report on BI, and play close attention to the cautions listed. MSTR is dying a slow death, losing out to innovative, nimble companies such as Tableau. In 5 years, MSTR will be the next Britches Great Outdoor, Hechingers, or Woodward and Lothrops--all defunct Metro-area business that were once relevant. I could honestly go on forever in this section--withheld bonuses, public reprimands, blatant nepotism, and a thousand other negatives that make MSTR the laughing stock of the Metro area. Just ask the technology professional sitting next to you; they probably have an MSTR horror story of their own to tell. Go ahead, I will wait. See, I told you ;)

It upsets me a great deal that I agree with most of what the negative entries say as I did enjoy a decent amount of time at MicroStrategy. It's nothing short of tragic what has become of what was by most accounts an industry leader in BI. There are companies with bad executive management. review_title: Can be fine for new grads; Definite torture for seasoned professionals
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: It's an OK place to be if you're a new graduate and this is your first work experience. Although not always true, you will likely stay far enough away from the toxicity. if you're lucky you may learn something useful for the first few years. Also, if you're desperate for a paycheck they do pay salaries, and sometimes they even pay the bonus that you're promised.
cons: If you're a seasoned professional, prepare to be told: 1) everything you've learned throughout your career is useless, 2) you have no idea how to do your job, and 3) you should be replaced by a 22 year old new graduate that just does what they're told. review_title: Where dreams go to DIE, BEWARE of ALL positive/glowing reviews, you’ve been warned!
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 8 years
pros: They do have a decent bootcamp training to get you up to speed with the platform. The immediate people you work with. Great bunch of highly intelligent, knowledgeable and dedicated individuals who’s talent is being squandered. A decent free gym in the same building with shower facilities and free classes. Next to Tyson’s corner mall.
cons: I’d be skeptical of ALL recent positive reviews, I highly doubt they’re real/authentic and more of a marketing counter strategy to the actual honest reviews making the real truth come out. You think you’ll be rewarded for going that extra mile and putting MANY hours of overtime for a given project? Think again, you’ll just be reassigned and your credit for the previous project will be discarded. Adverse situations outside of your control WILL hurt you. Let’s say your manager changed three times within the course of a year to a year and a half. Come your annual review, the latest manager will NOT acknowledge all your work from previous years leading up to a much deserved promotion. Isn’t that a gem? Wipe the slate clean, throw all of your blood, sweat and tears for years out the door! So you see senior management get promoted and their titles change more than once within a business year. You think to yourself, hey, I’ll work my butt off to achieve that, nope, sorry no budget for you and in spite of performing above and beyond, it’s still not enough to qualify! Be prepared to be underpaid compared to industry standards. The irony is that if you applied for your same job as an external applicant you’d make more money and when asking to be compensated accordingly in terms of salary adjustment, you’ll always be given the runaround that you’re within the proper payment bracket. Fancy way of dodging the bullet. You CAN and WILL be screwed out of your bonus and promotions MULTIPLE times with claims such as ‘there’s no budget’ or ‘next quarter’ an then they turnaround and hire ten new people or say there was an outstanding quarter/year but never fulfill the bonus/promotion promises. Like a horse with a dangling carrot. Once? Twice? nope, it kept on happening over the years, UNACCEPTABLE! No wonder the company’s KEY talent that is the foundation of it’s success keeps going for exodus. Oh! Pray you never have a serious personal/family emergency in nearly 10 years and the first/only time you DO have to take time off because of it because it WILL be held against you and be told verbatim ‘it doesn’t matter why, you haven’t been here’. Support from your manger when a family member is critically ill to the point you break down in front of them? Forget it! They’ll literally turn their head away from you and prompt you to stop bothering them.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for less than a year

cons: Let's see....I was put through an intensive 6 weeks of training, only to be laid off along with 20% of the company about 3 months after my training ended. And in those 3 months of "real work," my department went through a massive re-org so I didn't have anything to do. I switched teams twice, and there was no direction as to what the heck was happening/was going to happen. Soon enough, because of Usher, the worst access/security app ever, we got an announcement that the company was going to start laying off people to try to balance the losses from Usher. So for the last month I was there, I watched so many people either quit or get laid off. The atmosphere was AWFUL. Managers could care less about their employees. I heard stories that some higher level managers would take time off during the week their employees were getting laid off, not answering phone calls or emails, basically just hiding. Lots of people were laid off during their first week, after moving from various places to start this "cool new job." Honestly, I have to say I was relieved when I finally got the notice that I was to be laid off. Can't say I lost much because the only thing I really learned at MSTR was from my 6 weeks of training (funny thing is they laid off the majority of the training team too). All I knew was that MSTR was a total waste of my time.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Get an expensive education and life lesson – what not to do, where not to work and what to look for in your next job.
cons: MicroStrategy is truly the black hole where innovation, excitement, ideas, hope and love for your job goes to die. It’s a company that is run with an iron fist by an egoistic leader who leads by intimidation and encourages top down management by other leaders who have been put in that position not because of their leadership style – but because they will follow what he says. MicroStrategy is the new walking dead – it’s a place where the CEO believes that his biggest asset is his software and not his people; it’s a place where you are absolutely worthless – just an empty shell peddling his software; it’s a place where the core software has seen no innovation in the past few years; it’s a place where there is no fun, no culture, low camaraderie and no growth; it’s a place where you WILL get scammed out of your commission/bonus someway, somehow, sometime; it’s a place that you really don’t want to be. If you love your family, and want to work in a place that respects you as a human being – stay away.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Some of the most successful selling years of my career were at MicroStrategy. Great President's Club trips. Excellent pre-sales talent. Strong core analytics platform.
cons: I'm glad you asked. Where to begin? The worst part of a sales cycle at MicroStrategy is trying to get buy in from legal and finance. I expect this is partially why the company prefers to simply milk the customer base. There was essentially zero marketing support save for some roll of the dice on a once up and coming golf pro whose name no one remembers. The company's "laser" focus on analytics seems to be the problem in the eyes of the founder and CEO, so he works tirelessly to try and come up with the next version of sliced bread all the while sucking valuable resources from the core analytics platform. And the cycle just repeats. Upper management is deaf, likely the result of the CEO yelling at them. The massive layoffs compounded by more employees getting fed up and leaving means everyone is doing "more with less" making it difficult to get the support you need from the company to close business. The upside there is that you have a lot of independence... The whole thing is unfortunate. The product is very strong and the customer base is very loyal (indentured?). But management pokes customers in the ribs with sharp sticks on an annual basis. If you are a mercenary and could not care less about a career path or whether the company will do the right thing or simply disappear, etc. then MicroStrategy is a great fit for you. I made a lot of money for which I am very thankful, but view the investment I made in the company over 5 years as not delivering the return I had expected. It's more fun to make money and feel good about the company you work for.

cons: Can be hard to transition to a new role. Lack of support from senior management.

review_title: Company & morale re-boot in full swing
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: Company offers great benefits, free covered parking and much more in a professional but flexible working atmosphere. There is a lot to do and there are a lot of smart/nice people working here - both of which really help you stay busy and engaged. The company is working hard to change the morale climate now. Quite a few company sponsored summer events!!
cons: Not many to speak of so it sort of depends on your perspective. Best advice is to do your work well and communicate thoroughly if you have questions, concerns or problems. As long as you follow these steps, you should be fine.

review_title: Done with the rough patch, it's now safe to work there
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: The Q2-2014 results triggered a massive restructuring and layoff round. You can tell, because the company rating here tanked at exactly the same time. It has taken them 10 months for upper management to get out of stop-the-pain mode and into providing a consistent view of the future.and a clear plan for how we're going to get there. The levels of management flapping are now back to historic averages, and will likely stay that way for a couple more years. This is the time to get on. This company was one of the most diverse companies I've ever worked for. When I was interviewed for a highly technical role, both of my interviewers were not white men. Very rare, and much appreciated. The company is also focusing on employee retention right now, so now is a great time to get on board.
cons: When things get hard, they get opaque and change can come without warning. There is a strong culture of secrecy in management, so for individual contributors we get sweeping and vast change announced fait-acompli, and we had no idea that our own management was waging wars in meetings for a month beforehand. The company is focusing on revitalizing workplace culture and is not friendly to remote-working. Telecommute has actually gotten harder these days.

review_title: Returning employee and not at all disappointed!
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: I won't lie the company is coming out of a difficult time, but everyone here appears to be past it and looking forward to the future. I noticed they're aggressively hiring again and hopefully the positive energy from the new hires will be infectious. The product is an industry leader and the stock is at a 52 week high. I'm the type to look ahead and not back.
cons: Like I said above, the layoffs from a year ago have changed the culture. The employees don't want to hear talk from Management they want actions. All teams are stretched thin which makes it hard to execute.

review_title: So much potential yet poorly aimed vision

review_title: Change is good but needs a better way to transition.
main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Was a good company to work for. Nice work-life balance and decent pay. Nice people to work with. Lower down the hierarchy, direct managers in technology were excellent before the multiple restructurings. Great for new people who didn't know how much better it was a few years ago. They get trained instead of re-educated.
cons: My personal issue was that my position was virtually eliminated overnight. They didn't lay me off but with no title or no official duties, I got the hint that they didn't really appreciate the work my team and I do. So the team I worked with got split up, the workload we technically aren't supposed to work on but need to complete doubled, no pay raise, an insult of a bonus and a constant ear full from the higher ups. While people were leaving, you would expect something to be done to retain the remaining employees. It seems like they do not care and would rather hire new, more malleable employees. Somewhat like a purge of any sort ideas from before 2013. I think the biggest issue people were having was too much change and no clean way to transition causing confusion and frustration.

pros: Engineers were intelligent and hard-working. Current product offering is best in class. Good work-life balance. Descent benefits and time offs.

pros: Good location in Tysons Corner, near the mall Nice gym Very nice co-workers Garage parking Decent work hours, 8 per day

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Difficult to find. Occasional Company Days do not help replace the knowledge that went lost.
cons: The future: if you fire 40% of your employees you can't pretend you have just made efficiency, you have to some extent (let's say 10%) but the rest? You have only tried to save on costs by massively firing people. Infact, profits are higher because of costs cutting and revenues are lower. Fine to cut costs, but massive firing will take its toll in 12-18 months. Competitors: version 10 is just cosmetic change from 9.5, it could well be a 9.6. Competitors like Tableau and, above all, QlikView, are closing the gap and investing (=hiring) in sales and technical staff while you are abandoning markets, especially international ones. Lots of ex-MSTR are now working for Qlik and replacing MSTR with QlikView at customers. That is logic if you fire a Directors and do not replace them and they are hired by a competitor.

It was a wonderful time to meet other people and understand the pitfalls as well as key items which made them successful. Microstrategy gives full potential to earn your bonuses which is not a paltry sum by any means.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The everyday engineers and mid-level managers are among the most talented and dedicated in the industry. The community within Support was, and still is, one of the best memories of my career. Support's leadership fought hard and long for individual success. I got to travel a fair share for the position and see most of the US. The pay used to be good years ago, but has not kept up with the industry.
cons: The amount of stress was substantial and entirely driven by uncertainty and worry. Executive management is entirely walled off and major decisions change twice a week. For 2015, the constant reorganizations meant that previously owed salary increases for promotions and bonuses were quietly dropped. Every 6 months or so, the executive staff is reorganized and new leadership is brought in with promises of improvement and better compensation. All failed to live up to the hype. Those reorganizations came with promises of growth and resources to support new roles, but they have failed to provide anything to make them successful.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year
pros: Good work/life balance mostly because upper management has no idea what they're doing so you could go long periods of time without meaningful work. They used to hire really bright people so you have great coworkers to share in your frustration of how bad upper management is.
cons: Massive disconnect between the executives and the employees. Upper management doesn't give a rat's tail about their employees until they realize everyone's leaving and they're massively understaffed. Promises are made and broken on a regular basis about employee placement. They choose to completely ignore the people who have been there for 15+ years who actually know what they're doing in favor of new people they've brought in over the past year who refuse to listen to anyone's idea other than their own. Also, it's no secret that everyone is being underpaid. It's almost like they're trying to get people to leave and then somehow they're surprised when they start hemorrhaging employees.

review_title: I do not enjoy this place

cons: MicroStrategy is turning into a very chaotic place to work. I would definitely suggest not working at this company. There is no career potential or upward mobility for hard workers.

review_title: At least the health plan covers therapy.
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: Used to be pretty good. Tech Support department was insulated from the huge layoffs and reorgs in 2014. Nobody gives you crap for leaving on time at the end of the day. Benefits are pretty good.
cons: New senior management decided to reorg Tech Support for the heck of it, breaking up functional product-oriented teams with good chemistry and reassigning everyone randomly according to regional business units. Completely nonsensical. Non-technical people were put in charge of this process and have no idea what they are doing, so now they are shooting first and asking questions later. To add insult to injury the new management has also decided not to pay out quarterly bonuses as agreed upon previously (and to be completely incommunicado as to why or what's going on). Employees were informed that the changes were due to Michael Saylor's desire to make every department responsible for their own profitability. How does that make any sense for Tech Support?

main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy for more than 5 years
pros: The people I worked with were great and extremely knowledgeable. It's sad to see that the majority of them have now left the company or have plans to leave.
cons: I have worked in multiple departments at this company and have seen dissatisfaction from many of the employees. The employees do not get compensated for their hard work and the bonuses for Q1 were cut in HALF for the Tech Support department. Not to mention, when employees are promoted, their compensation stays the same. This is another main reason why people keep leaving this company. It seems that the executives think the people in Tech Support are easily replaceable as if the years of experience with the product can be replaced in a matter of weeks or months. There practically will be no Tech Support department with the rate knowledgeable employees are leaving. Almost everyone I know in that department has plans of quitting, or are thinking about quitting. Every week more and more talented support engineers are leaving the company and the more the executives ignore this issue, the more it is apparent that they do not care about the quality of service customers will receive when calling into Technical Support. Sure, you can hire newbies as replacements but will they know how to solve P1 cases? Who will they turn to for help when the only people left in the department are newbies as well? The fact that the organizational structure in the Technical Support department was changed even though the majority, if not all, of the employees expressed their concerns and dissatisfaction, shows that the opinions of the employees were not taken into consideration by the executives. Also note that before the change happened, the upper level management team was given a list of the people who would leave if the department were to change. In regards to working in different departments, if you were to move to a different city with higher cost of living, you will NOT be compensated accordingly. Try living in a city where the rent is more than half of your monthly salary. Also, the phrase “Let me get back to you” seems to be the phrase of choice when upper level management is confronted about issues such as compensation, project availability, etc. Poor communication among the different levels of management is another huge con. All compensation changes, and financial decisions have to go through the CEO so the process takes an enormous amount of time. If you do some research you will notice that the majority of consultants at this company are GDC consultants. If GDC consultants were to leave the company, they would have to leave the country as well due to Visa reasons. Because of this, most of them are basically forced to stay with the company. It is an ongoing trend that if you have the ability to leave the company (US citizen), you will most likely do so and I have seen plenty of other consultants who end up leaving within 6 months due to the poor compensation, and project availability. If you look at Lithium (Forum for consultants) you will notice that a lot of consultants are on the bench and are not staffed on projects. Sure, consultants have "uncapped" quarterly bonuses, but it doesn't really matter when you can't get on a billable project. Also take into consideration that the employees in the Technical Support department were only given 50% of their Q1 bonuses...

pros: It still makes good technology, the work life balance is great, there's a gym, and if you're not near any of the chaos (e.g. in a field position) it's probably not that bad.
cons: The company has become incredibly frustrating to work for. There's some law in physics about how isolated closed systems tend towards maximum entropy. There is no more isolated closed system than MicroStrategy. Recommendations from analysts, employees, clients, executives who were hired externally (and then promptly fired or whipped into submission), etc., all go unheeded by the highest executives like an action sequence in a comic book. "We think you should focus less on your 'security' product and more on analytics" says the analyst. KABLAM, here's 2.5 hours of Usher during our keynote sessions at World. "We think you should show more compassion towards employees after last year's two rounds of layoffs" says someone in human resources. POW WHAM BAM, let's forget about employee morale, consider skipping this annual cycle of raises, then settle on just giving people delayed minimal raises with zero transparency about our motivations. "We think we need to focus on these 5 things to fix our sales and marketing pipeline" says the new executive marketing team. ZABOINGO, nope not today, how about we fire you and then slash marketing's budget. The chaos trickles down, too. One week you'll be working on Project A which is most definitely a "top priority" and then your manager's manager will have a meeting with a particular executive and that executive says "Project A is worthless, why were you ever working on it, we need to focus on Project B." So now you're working on Project B with no real idea why it's better or more important than Project A was. And this happens ad infinitum until you're working on Project Z and all excitement and jubilance you had when you started your job has drained out of you like a diamond ring down a toilet. As an employee this is frustrating because your ideas have no value, you never learn what "best practices" are, and you feel totally worthless.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time
pros: Compensation packages, especially for account executives, are good Key products are helping the company stay afloat Some innovative new products Employees who meet/exceed quota every year get a nice vacation
cons: When a company asks its employees to write positive reviews on Glassdoor because so many others have been negative, that's a big red flag that something is wrong. In addition to Microstrategy cooking the books a few years ago (according to the SEC), it seems they are also trying to manipulate their reviews. For an honest review of the company, read the negative reviews here in the last 6 months or so. Ever since the CEO decided to come back to manage the company (after spending too much time on his yachts, going to Hollywood parties, and being a bachelor playboy who hangs out with 18 year old bikini models) as a result of the Apex letter, the company has been in a downward spiral. Not only did they lay off a significant percentage of the workforce in an attempt to show profitability, but most of the company's best and brightest employees have left or are in the process of leaving, primarily due to poor management. In the corporate office, employees are terrified. The mood and morale there is lower than I have ever seen. No one knows if they will be let go the next day or if their manager will be forced out or leave for a better position elsewhere. In the field, it's much the same: all of the best account executives and sales engineers are leaving. I think that speaks to how poorly managed the company is, and that comes from the top down. As others have said, the CEO thinks he is the smartest person in the company, and none of the top executives are willing to contradict him (because those that do end up being shown the door). He surrounds himself with "yes" men as a result, so bad decisions run rampant. No wonder it is a sinking ship and all the good people are fleeing. When it comes to commissions, the commission structure changes all the time. It isn't unusual to work on an account and expect a large commission only to find that the company has found some reason not to pay you the commission you expect. Microstrategy has some great products, and Usher shows a lot of promise. But there are so many internal problems, it's hard to see how the company will continue with the kind of success they had before the CEO came back to "manage". Everyone I know is looking for jobs elsewhere, and the brain drain is evident.

review_title: MicroStrategy . . . THE definition of Executive Lunacy
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Advanced technology. Smart and collaborative workers. Folks rolled up their sleeves and worked together here in the past. Vacation and medical benefits are good.
cons: Just one that is the root of ALL others: The CEO, Michael Saylor. He views himself as above all others, and as the sole reason that the company has had any success. Don’t forget that fact when dealing with him. If you do, you will feel the wrath of a small man pretending to be a big shot business leader, who is desperately and pathetically hoping he’ll someday be in the conversation along with the great technology innovators of our time. MicroStrategy used to be a great place to work. Well, all that changed when Mr. Saylor’s performance as CEO was put into question by people he couldn’t bully: Institutional Investors. The punishment for their discovery of his own lavish, company-funded extravagancies, was a full-force, and in rapid succession, set of austerity measures for his employees. Also a large set of draconian processes to be adopted immediately and forcefully. And a hiring spree of unnecessary executives who may have had honest aspirations of leading the company, but in reality, are now Yes Men hanging around just long enough to cash in their options grant. Mr. Saylor is completely out of touch with his work force (not that he cares), and the reality of the situation he’s recently created at MicroStrategy. The company is being systemically destroyed by a dictatorial figurehead. He has single-handedly wiped out the existing culture and has driven away a very experienced and tenured human-talent base. TO BE CLEAR: ALL of the Top Engineering and Sales talent has already left or is currently leaving. All that is left is a single-minded CEO, and his Executive staff nodding their bowed heads in fealty and submission. This is the BI Titanic sinking here. Make sure you get off the ship while there are still life boats available.

main_text: I worked at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year

cons: - Very corporate "uncool" feel compared to other tech companies your friends might be working at - Executive management is changing faster than you can keep track of (not even sure who my boss's boss is anymore) - Company is not focusing on its core product in favor of questionable side projects - Technical skill development is surprisingly low for a supposed engineering position - Advancement to managerial positions is purely by length of tenure - Not much work if you're efficient. On a good day, I will do only 2-3 hours of real work. - After initial training, professional development is nonexistent. There used to be an Academy program, but they phased it out after the 2014 cutbacks. - Low base bay

review_title: This company is made for Reality TV...the ratings would be fantastic.
main_text: I have been working at MicroStrategy full-time for more than a year

cons: The past six months have been constant chaos and drama. Decisions are made on a dime, no one can keep up with the latest process, org chart, territory. Our CEO makes EVERY decision. He throws tantrums like a child, yells at his Executive Team and fires people because they do not tell him what he wants to hear. This organization is so disgruntled and depressed. Look at the previous post. Our CEO has a 9% approval rating and the executives or our three person HR team has done nothing to address the elephant in the room... they have no power. IT IS SO HARD TO GET ANYTHING DONE! Simple tasks are incredibly challenging and requires diligent follow-up. Our internal systems are held together by a thread and you can not make updates without asking Congress to pass a Bill. So many people have left that there are so many holes in the organization. The latest organization has sales competing with each other and does not compensate our Sale Engineers to work together as a team to sell Enterprise Software...as well as our Cyber Security product that doesn't work. Where is the marketing? Hire the Kardashian Family, they could actually execute something for us. If the excuse is we have very few people in marketing, then hire a agency. Our organization is so broken. It is beyond repair. And just when we think it can not get any worse, it does.
